title: 108_hr4760
content: The Act may be cited as the "DSHEA Full Implementation and Enforcement Act of 2004". Congress finds that over 158 million Americans use dietary supplements, with consumer spending reaching $17.1 billion in 2000. The FDA predicts continued growth in supplement use due to factors like aging populations and scientific advancements. The DSHEA was enacted in 1994 to regulate dietary supplements. The Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act (DSHEA) of 1994 balanced consumer access to supplements, increased research, public education, and consumer protections. DSHEA requires truthful, non-misleading claims on labels, sets manufacturing standards, and mandates safety information for new ingredients. The FDA has updated its system for reporting adverse events related to dietary supplements. DSHEA provides authorities to remove unsafe supplements and created the Office of Dietary Supplements for research and consumer information. The FDA has not effectively enforced DSHEA and requires more resources for implementation. The FDA has allocated additional funds beyond the President's budget to enforce DSHEA, totaling $9,700,000 in fiscal year 2003. However, the FDA states that full implementation of DSHEA would require between $24,000,000 and $65,000,000 annually. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION AND APPROPRIATION OF RESOURCES. Authorization of appropriations for the Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994 and regulatory requirements under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act for fiscal years 2005 to 2009: $20,000,000 for 2005, $30,000,000 for 2006, $40,000,000 for 2007, $50,000,000 for 2008, and $65,000,000 for 2009. The Food and Drug Administration is authorized to use funds to regulate dietary supplements under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. $30,000,000 is allocated for expanded research and development of consumer information on dietary supplements for fiscal year 2005, with additional funding for subsequent years. Annual accountability report required on the regulation of dietary supplements. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit an annual report to Congress on the implementation and enforcement of the Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994. The report includes details on funding and personnel dedicated to dietary supplement regulation and adverse event reporting systems within the Food and Drug Administration. The annual report to Congress includes details on funding and personnel dedicated to enforcement of dietary supplement labeling, good manufacturing practices inspections, and new ingredient reviews by the Food and Drug Administration. It also summarizes the number of inspections and enforcement actions taken. The annual report to Congress includes details on enforcement actions by the Food and Drug Administration and the Department of Health related to dietary supplements, requests for substantiation of supplement claims, determination of false claims, research and education activities supported by the Office of Dietary Supplements, and any recommendations for administrative or legislative actions. The annual report to Congress includes details on enforcement actions related to dietary supplements, requests for substantiation of supplement claims, determination of false claims, research and education activities, and any recommendations for regulatory actions.
